bug.short_desc: Do not pollute stdout with asserts

long_desc.thetext: Description of problem ====================== Unlike `rlLog*`, `rlFail` and `rlPass` still print to stdout, which breaks cases in which they are called inside a routine that produces useful data. Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable) ============================================================ beakerlib-1.9-3.fc20.noarch How reproducible ================ Always Steps to Reproduce ================== rlFail hello 2>/dev/null rlPass hello 2>/dev/null Actual results ============== Decorated "hello"s Expected results ================ No stdout (greetings to /dev/null ;)) Additional info =============== In bug 483014 comment 14, Dalibor already proposed this behavior for `rlLog*` functions and from what I can see from behavior, it has been already changed in those. However, rlFail, rlPass, and possibly others still print to stdout. For a more specific example where this is problem, consider a routine that scans upstream suite for tests and then runs them. During the scan one or more tests may be detected invalid, in that case rlFail is used to trigger overall result of Warning (the routine is in Setup phase) and attract attention to detailed output. rlFail breaks the code further down--by mixing a decorated message into list of valid tests.

This bug appears to have been reported against 'rawhide' during the Fedora 22 development cycle. Changing version to '22'. More information and reason for this action is here: https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Fedora_Program_Management/HouseKeeping/Fedora22

Thanks for the catch. It sounds reasonable to unite all asserts (not just rlFail/rlPass) to print to stderr instead of stdout. However, this change of behaviour which break actual tests so we need to spread the info and ask folks if they are OK with it before fixing this bug.
Why the low priority? People have to jump through hoops to work around this. Please don't let this rot...

Fedora 22 changed to end-of-life (EOL) status on 2016-07-19. Fedora 22 is no longer maintained, which means that it will not receive any further security or bug fix updates. As a result we are closing this bug. If you can reproduce this bug against a currently maintained version of Fedora please feel free to reopen this bug against that version. If you are unable to reopen this bug, please file a new report against the current release. If you experience problems, please add a comment to this bug. Thank you for reporting this bug and we are sorry it could not be fixed.
